title: Opinion: Lamar Jackson's anger gave Ravens what they needed to beat Seahawks
text:
SEATTLE — Lamar Jackson’s frustration had reached near combustible levels.

He had the Baltimore Ravens in scoring position at the 16-yard line on a crucial late third-quarter possession against the hosting Seattle Seahawks. But then that opportunity seemingly started slipping away.

First, tight end Mark Andrews dropped a perfectly-placed pass in the end zone. Then, center Matt Skura couldn’t hear Jackson clap for the ball because of the deafening cheers of the Seahawks faithful and drew a delay of game penalty, after which Jackson slammed the ball — once he finally did get it — to the turf in rage.

Two plays later, with his team facing fourth-and-2, coach John Harbaugh was content to settle for a field goal to break a 13-13 tie. But nah, man. That complacency didn’t sit well with Jackson. As the field goal unit trotted onto the field, the seething second-year quarterback made a beeline for his coach and demanded a change in play calls.

“I told him, ‘We’re going for it,’” Jackson later recounted. “I told him to go for it because we needed to score. We had moved the ball down the field twice. We’re not kicking a field goal because Russell Wilson’s getting the ball again, and if we didn’t score, it might look ugly.”

Harbaugh listened and promptly called timeout to swap units. He told Jackson he was putting the ball in his hands.

As he strode back onto the field, everything about Jackson’s body language spoke to the frustration and determination that boiled within him. So it wasn’t at all surprising when he took the shotgun snap, sprinted up the middle on a designed run called “quarterback power,” slipped between defenders and scored from 8 yards out.

“I just got mad,” Jackson told USA TODAY Sports during a talk in front of his locker a short time after helping carry to his Ravens to a 30-16 victory on Sunday. “We’d already been down there twice and came away with just six points when it should’ve been 14 to whatever. ... Aint no way we can put our defense back out there with three points. That wasn’t going to help us. … When I took that snap, knew I had to get the first down. Everyone was outside, so I hit the lane, got the first down and scored, actually.”

Jackson’s touchdown run, which came with 1:24 left in the third quarter, ignited a Baltimore squad that had struggled to find firm footing both literally and figuratively on a rain-soaked day at CenturyLink Field. But the play did more than spark a 17-3 scoring run that the Ravens used to clinch their fifth victory of the season.

For one, Jackson also made good on a promise. Sunday’s game represented both a homecoming and shot at vindication for Ravens safety Earl Thomas.

The last time Seattle fans saw Thomas, he was in their their uniform, riding on the back of the medical cart with a broken leg and giving coach Pete Carroll the finger. He had played that day despite not having a long-term contract from the team — a deal he believed he had earned — and one of his greatest fears, a season-ending injury, happened. Seattle never did extend that contract offer to the six-time Pro Bowl selection, and he signed with Baltimore in free agency.

So, throughout the week leading up to Thomas’ return to Seattle, Jackson kept telling his teammate, “I’m going to put you on my back, put the team on my back if I got to, and we are going to win.”

Jackson rushed for 116 yards and the touchdown on 14 carries and passed for another 143 yards. The Ravens’ defense added two touchdowns — a 67-yard interception returned for a touchdown by cornerback Marcus Peters in the second quarter, and an 18-yard fumble recovery return by cornerback Marlon Humphrey with 3:37 left in the game. But teammates, including Thomas, credited Jackson for energizing the Ravens in their definitive final quarter-and-a-half.

“Lamar Jackson — I can’t say enough about that cat, bro,” Thomas said. “When we needed him, he came through with his legs and his arm.”

Jackson’s performance carried greater meaning on a grander scale, however.

The sequence that led to led up to his touchdown run represented another level of maturation for Jackson, who continues his ascension from promising project player to bona fide NFL franchise quarterback and game-changer.

Jackson meant no disrespect as he barked at Harbaugh, insisting a deviation from his original plans. His demanding the ball didn’t represent a lack of faith in his teammates. Instead, Jackson was simply taking complete ownership of Baltimore’s offense and chances to win. His insistence on carrying the group reflected the maturation, confidence and determination necessary to elevate the franchise to the ranks of contenders.

The AFC features the New England Patriots and a pack of hopefuls without clear distinction. With the Kansas City Chiefs having lost three straight and facing the likelihood of missing Patrick Mahomes for three weeks, according to reports, the Ravens have a very real opportunity to distinguish themselves as their quarterback grows up in front of their eyes.

It’s clear that his development remains a process. He displays big-play passing ability but also displays a need for improved accuracy. However, his decision-making has improved dramatically from his rookie season. And his aggressive mindset and leadership compensate for his inexperience and any lingering deficiencies. Ask any Ravens player, and they will tell you that Jackson makes them believe, and that’s half the battle.

“He shows a lot of resilience and character, able to step up when the game is on the line,” running back Mark Ingram told USA TODAY Sports. “He’s only going to get better. … Everything y’all see, he’s going to continue to improve. Things that he’s already good at, he’s only going to improve. You’re just going to see his stock keep rising.”

The respect that Jackson commands extends beyond his own locker room. Everyone from Wilson to Jadeveon Clowney sang his praises following Sunday’s game, and Seahawks players discussed both the fear that Jackson strikes when he takes off running and their admiration for his passing ability, which they deem underappreciated.

Everyone wants to be respected for what they do. But Jackson — in another reflection of maturity — cares about just one thing for now: achieving Baltimore’s ultimate goal of winning a Super Bowl. He is careful to point out that he and the Ravens really haven’t accomplished anything. Less than an hour after the game had ended, his mind already had shifted forward to the next hurdle.

“Really, we got another W, what we want and needed,” he said. “But we’ve got a bye week coming up, and it’s time to get ready for the Patriots. It’s not like we won the Super Bowl.”

description: When the Ravens planned to settle for a field goal, Lamar Jackson got mad. That anger proved to be key in the win over the Seahawks.
